title: 112_hr1409
content: The "Quality Health Care Coalition Act of 2011" allows health care professionals to negotiate with health plans without violating federal antitrust laws. Health care professionals negotiating with health plans are exempt from Federal antitrust laws. The exemption does not grant the right to collectively stop providing services to patients or change the National Labor Relations Act for professionals excluded from it. The National Labor Relations Act does not apply to negotiations between health care professionals and health plans regarding benefits provided under specific federal programs such as Medicare, Medicaid, SCHIP, and others. Chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code pertains to the Federal employees' health benefits program, while the Indian Health Care Improvement Act is covered under 25 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions for "antitrust laws" and "group health plan" are provided. Antitrust laws encompass laws related to unfair competition, including state laws. A group health plan is an employee welfare benefit plan that offers medical care to employees and their dependents. The curr_chunk defines terms related to health care services, including group health plans, health insurance issuers, health care services, and health care professionals. It clarifies that these terms also include third-party administrators or individuals providing health care items or services. The curr_chunk defines health insurance coverage as benefits for medical care under policies offered by health insurance issuers, which are licensed insurance entities subject to state law. The curr_chunk defines health maintenance organizations as entities regulated under State law for solvency, and health plans as group health plans or health insurance issuers offering coverage. The curr_chunk defines medical care as amounts paid for diagnosis, cure, treatment, or prevention of disease, and includes transportation essential for receiving such services. The term "person" includes States and local governments, while "State" encompasses various regions including the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. The Act will be effective from the date of enactment and does not apply to conduct before that date.
